moves.1. e4 c5 2. Ne2 g6 3. d3 Bg7 4. Nf4 e6 5: whatever taste they come in: always strive for d5...
moves.14. Re1 Bf6: mainly avoiding Ng5: covering Ne7, releases the Queen...
moves.16. Nb1 Rb8 17. Ne2 b5: Sicilian style: take over the Queens' wing...
moves.27. Qe2 Ng6 28. Re8: Re6, might have been more convincing: but then Qb4...
moves.28... d3 29. cxd3 cxd3: this is not going well for White...
moves.31. Qe3 Re7: a bad decision: from White, that is...
moves.34. Nc4: no less, than the losing move: this brings the Black Trojan Horse right in...
moves.35. Kh2: worth considering, might have been Ne3: but after Qxc3, bxc3, White has little to hope for...
moves.35... Qf2: threatening mate in one: plus many more threats, like Re1...
moves.36. Qf6+ Kg8: White has to keep on giving check: after Rg1, Re1...
moves.37. Qd8+ Kg7 38. Qd7+ Kh6: it is over: the White Queen outplayed itself; there are no more checks... in this position, White timed out after three minutes of doing nothing...

gameName: fiercequeen walking Sicilian across the hall (final)...
